Regularization for Shuffled Data Problems via Exponential Family Priors on the Permutation Group

Abstract

In the analysis of data sets consisting of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y)-pairs, a tacit assumption is that each pair corresponds to the same observation unit. If, however, such pairs are obtained via record linkage of two files, this assumption can be violated as a result of mismatch error rooting, for example, in the lack of reliable identifiers in the two files. Recently, there has been a surge of interest in this setting under the term â€œShuffled dataâ€ in which the underlying correct pairing of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y)-pairs is represented via an unknown index permutation. Explicit modeling of the permutation tends to be associated with substantial overfitting, prompting the need for suitable methods of regularization. In this paper, we propose a flexible exponential family prior on the permutation group for this purpose that can be used to integrate various structures such as sparse and locally constrained shuffling. This prior turns out to be conjugate for canonical shuffled data problems in which the likelihood conditional on a fixed permutation can be expressed as product over the corresponding (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y)-pairs. Inference is based on the EM algorithm in which the intractable E-step is approximated by the Fisher-Yates algorithm. The M-step is shown to admit a significant reduction from n2superscriptğ‘›2n^{2} to nğ‘›n terms if the likelihood of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y)-pairs has exponential family form as in the case of generalized linear models. Comparisons on synthetic and real data show that the proposed approach compares favorably to competing methods.

1 Introduction

Shuffled data problems refer broadly to situations in which the goal is to perform inference for a functional of the joint distribution of a pair of random variables (ğ±,ğ²)ğ±ğ²(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}) (such as, e.g., their covariance) based on separate samples {ğ±i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and {ğ²i}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘š\{\mathbf{y}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m} that involve matching pairs {(XÏ€âˆ—â€‹(i),Yi)}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹superscriptğœ‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘š\{(X_{\pi^{*}(i)},Y_{i})\}_{i=1}^{m} pertaining to the same statistical unit, where the map Ï€âˆ—:{1,â€¦,m}â†’{1,â€¦,n}:superscriptğœ‹â†’1â€¦ğ‘š1â€¦ğ‘›\pi^{*}:\{1,\ldots,m\}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,n\} may only be observed incompletely. This is a rather common scenario in data integration problems in which different pieces of information about a shared set of entities reside in multiple data sources that need to be combined in order to perform a given data analysis task. The process of identifying matching parts across two or more files is often far from trivial in the absence of unique identifiers, and has thus grown into a vast and active field of research known as record linkage (e.g., [1]). The above shuffled data model in terms of the unknown map Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} represents a direct approach to account for mismatches in record linkage and their impact on downstream data analysis. Historically, shuffled data problems were first systematically discussed in a series of papers by DeGroot et al.Â [2, 3, 4, 5], with little to no progress until only a few years ago given advances in computation [6]. Recently, shuffled data problems have generated much more widespread interest, fueled by novel applications in engineering and computer vision, among others [7, 8, 9]. Several papers have investigated the statistical limits of signal estimation and permutation recovery in unlabeled sensing in which the goal is to recover a signal Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*} from nğ‘›n noisy linear measurements yi=âŸ¨ğ±Ï€âˆ—â€‹(i),Î¸âˆ—âŸ©+Ïµisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ±superscriptğœ‹ğ‘–superscriptğœƒsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–y_{i}=\langle\mathbf{x}_{\pi^{*}(i)},\theta^{*}\rangle+\epsilon_{i}, 1â‰¤iâ‰¤n1ğ‘–ğ‘›1\leq i\leq n, where Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is an unknown index permutation [7, 8, 10, 11, 12]. Another line of research has studied similar permuted data settings in which xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y are scalar and related by a monotone transformation [13, 14, 15, 16, 17].

A common conclusion from these works is that shuffled data problems are generally plagued by both statistical and computational challenges. First, the combinatorial nature of Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} makes it hard to devise computationally tractable approaches with provable guarantees. Existing algorithmic â€œsolutionsâ€ involve integer programming [12, 18, 19] and the EM algorithm [20, 21, 6]. Regardless of the computational challenges, shuffled data problems tend to be highly susceptible to noise and prone to overfitting. In fact, statistical guarantees typically involve unrealistically stringent signal-to-noise requirements [8, 10, 22]. Loosely speaking, this issue results from the fact that the set of index permutations grows rapidly in size with nğ‘›n. This observation suggests that suitable forms of regularization hinging on prior information on Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} are needed to constrain the size of the parameter space under consideration. Several papers consider partial shufflings in which varying fractions of (ğ±i,ğ²i)subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ²ğ‘–(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i})-pairs are already observed with the correct correspondence [22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27], and only the remaining portion of the data is subject to shuffling. Another constraint commonly encountered in record linkage applications is that Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is block-structured with known composition of the blocks based on auxiliary variables that are required to agree for matching records [28, 29, 30]. In other applications such as signal processing and computer vision, Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is often constrained to act locally in the sense that indices are shuffled only within small time windows or image regions [31, 32].

The goal of the present paper is the development of a regularization framework for shuffled data problems that integrates the aforementioned as well as potential other constraints in a unified fashion. For this purpose, we introduce an exponential family prior on the permutation group that is flexible enough to accommodate any kind of prior information that can be expressed in terms of index pairs (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j). Conveniently, this prior turns out to be conjugate for canonical shuffled data problems in which the likelihood conditional on a fixed permutation can be expressed as the product over the corresponding (ğ±,ğ²)ğ±ğ²(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})-pairs. Inference is performed via the Monte-Carlo EM algorithm considered in earlier works [33, 21, 6]. We show that for exponential family likelihoods, the resulting M-step is particularly scalable since it only involves nğ‘›n instead of n2superscriptğ‘›2n^{2} terms. Moreover, computation of the MAP estimator of Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} with the remaining parameters fixed is shown to reduce to a linear assignment problem (LAP), and hence remains computationally tractable. Several theoretical results as well as a collection of experiments for various shuffled data settings demonstrate the usefulness of regularization based on the proposed prior in comparison to the unregularized counterpart and several other baselines. Paper organization. Section Â§Â§\S2 starts with a detailed motivation of the proposed approach, followed by a discussion of central technical and computational aspects. Section Â§Â§\S3 contains several theoretical results and accompanying discussions. Numerical results on synthetic and real data are presented in Â§Â§\S4. Proofs and complementary technical details are relegated to the appendix.

Conventions. We often refer to a permutation via the underlying map Ï€ğœ‹\pi and the corresponding matrix Î Î \Pi in an interchangeable fashion, and accordingly ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n) and subsets thereof may refer to both maps and matrices. 2 Approach

The following three subsections are dedicated to a detailed account of the approach. We start with a brief motivation before a more formal systematic introduction and subsequent technical details pertaining to computation and model fitting.

There are numerous applications in which Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is locally constrained such as genome sequencing [11], signal processing [38, 32], or computer vision [31].

2.2 Exponential family prior on ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n)

In this subsection, we show that the priors discussed in the two examples of the previous subsection can be understood as specific instances of a more general family of prior distributions over ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n). Specifically, we consider the family of priors

pâ€‹(Ï€)âˆexpâ¡(Î³â€‹trâ€‹(Î âŠ¤â€‹M)),Mâˆˆâ„nÃ—n,Î³>0,formulae-sequenceproportional-toğ‘ğœ‹ğ›¾trsuperscriptÎ topğ‘€formulae-sequenceğ‘€superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ›¾0p(\pi)\propto\exp(\gamma\,\mathrm{tr}(\Pi^{\top}M)),\quad M\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n},\quad\gamma>0, (6)

where Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 is the concentration parameter, and the matrix Mğ‘€M (which is not required to have any specific properties) defines the mode(s) of the distribution, i.e., argmaxÎ âˆˆğ’«â€‹(n)âŸ¨Î ,MâŸ©subscriptargmaxÎ ğ’«ğ‘›Î ğ‘€\operatorname*{argmax}_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\langle\Pi,M\rangle, where âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©â‹…â‹…\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle here represents the trace inner product on matrices of the same dimension that induces the Frobenius norm âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥Fsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â‹…F\lVert\cdot\rVert_{\textsf{F}}. In the same vein, the mode(s) of the distribution correspond to the set of matrices closest to Mğ‘€M with respect to the same norm. Moreover, the distribution specified by (6) is of exponential family form with respect to the trace inner product (cf., e.g., Â§Â§\S3.2 in [39]). Linear Assignment Problems. Linear Assignment problems (LAPs) are a well-studied class of optimization problems for computing optimal one-to-one matchings of two sets of items [40]. LAPs are of the form

where Cğ¶C is a given cost matrix. By the Birkhoff-von Neumann theorem [41], the vertices of the set of nğ‘›n-by-nğ‘›n doubly stochastic matrices

ğ’Ÿâ€‹ğ’®â€‹(n)={Pâˆˆâ„nÃ—n:Piâ€‹jâ‰¥0,â€„1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,âˆ‘j=1nPiâ€‹j=1,â€„â€‰1â‰¤iâ‰¤n,âˆ‘i=1nPiâ€‹j=1,â€„â€‰1â‰¤jâ‰¤n}ğ’Ÿğ’®ğ‘›conditional-setğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘—0formulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘—11ğ‘–ğ‘›formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘—11ğ‘—ğ‘›\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}(n)=\left\{P\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}:\;P_{ij}\geq 0,\;1\leq i,j\leq n,\;\sum_{j=1}^{n}P_{ij}=1,\;\,1\leq i\leq n,\;\sum_{i=1}^{n}P_{ij}=1,\;\,1\leq j\leq n\right\}

are given by ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n). As a result, the minimum over ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n) can be replaced by the minimum over ğ’Ÿâ€‹ğ’®â€‹(n)ğ’Ÿğ’®ğ‘›\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}(n), hence (7) reduces to a linear program in n2superscriptğ‘›2n^{2} variables and n2+2â€‹nsuperscriptğ‘›22ğ‘›n^{2}+2n linear constraints.

This brief summary entails that computing a mode of (6) reduces to a tractable problem, by setting C=âˆ’Mğ¶ğ‘€C=-M in (7).

Specific examples. Below, we consider a few examples of interest that are special cases of (6). (I) Hamming prior.
Consider the choice M=Inğ‘€subscriptğ¼ğ‘›M=I_{n}. In this case, for any Î âˆˆğ’«â€‹(n)Î ğ’«ğ‘›\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n), we have

which appeared in the first example of the preceding subsection Â§Â§\S2.1, cf.Â (4), in which the goal was to take into account the underlying low rate of mismatches. (II) Local shuffling prior.
As in the second example in Â§Â§\S2.1, suppose we want to have the prior pğ‘p place most of its mass on permutations that move indices within small windows, i.e., |Ï€â€‹(i)âˆ’i|ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘–|\pi(i)-i| tends to be small. This can be achieved by choosing the entries of the matrix Mğ‘€M in (6) of the form Miâ€‹j=âˆ’Ï•â€‹(|iâˆ’j|)subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—italic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—M_{ij}=-\phi(|i-j|) for some non-decreasing function Ï•:â„+â†’â„+:italic-Ï•â†’subscriptâ„subscriptâ„\phi:\mathbb{R}_{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}. The choice Ï•â€‹(u)=0italic-Ï•ğ‘¢0\phi(u)=0 if uâ‰¤rğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿu\leq r for some positive integer rğ‘Ÿr and Ï•â€‹(u)=+âˆitalic-Ï•ğ‘¢\phi(u)=+\infty otherwise yields the approach (5) that underlies the example in Figure 2 above. (III) Block prior.
Under the local shuffling assumption maxiâˆˆ[n]â¡|Ï€âˆ—â€‹(i)âˆ’i|â‰¤rsubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\max_{i\in[n]}|\pi^{*}(i)-i|\leq r, the corresponding permutation matrix Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*} is typically block diagonal, i.e., Î âˆ—=bdiagâ€‹(Î 1âˆ—,â€¦,Î Bâˆ—)superscriptÎ bdiagsuperscriptsubscriptÎ 1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptÎ ğµ\Pi^{*}=\text{bdiag}(\Pi_{1}^{*},\ldots,\Pi^{*}_{B}), with all BğµB blocks having size proportional to rğ‘Ÿr. Note that the composition of the blocks is generally not known in advance. On the other hand, in record linkage applications, it is rather common that the composition of the blocks is indeed known given matching variables used during record linkage. For example, suppose that the combination of gender, ethnicity, and age group are used for that purpose and that these three categorical variables are free of errors. In this case, mismatches can only involve pairs (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) falling into the same block corresponding to a specific combination of gender, ethnicity, and age. Such known block structure can be encoded via prior (6) by choosing Miâ€‹j=âˆ’âˆsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—M_{ij}=-\infty if (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) is not contained in the same block and Miâ€‹j=0subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—0M_{ij}=0 otherwise. Note that this corresponds to a uniform prior for each block, i.e., pâ€‹(Ï€)=âˆb=1Bpâ€‹(Ï€b)ğ‘ğœ‹superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘1ğµğ‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘p(\pi)=\prod_{b=1}^{B}p(\pi_{b}) with pâ€‹(Ï€b)âˆ1proportional-toğ‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘1p(\pi_{b})\propto 1, 1â‰¤bâ‰¤B1ğ‘ğµ1\leq b\leq B. The prior for each block does not have to be necessarily uniform. For example, a Hamming prior as in Example (I) above can be used instead. Moreover, the hard block constraint can be softened by choosing a suitable finite negative number for entries Miâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—M_{ij} corresponding to pairs (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) not contained in the same block. (IV) Lahiri-Larsen prior.
In their seminal work on adjusting (generalized) linear regression in the presence of mismatch errors, Lahiri & Larsen [47] and Chambers [28] assume that Ï€âˆ—âˆ¼pâ€‹(Ï€)similar-tosuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğœ‹\pi^{*}\sim p(\pi) whose expectation ğ„pâ€‹(Ï€)â¡[Î âˆ—]=Qsubscriptğ„ğ‘ğœ‹superscriptÎ ğ‘„\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{p(\pi)}[\Pi^{*}]=Q is known to the (post-linkage) data analyst. Observe that Qâˆˆğ’Ÿâ€‹ğ’®â€‹(n)ğ‘„ğ’Ÿğ’®ğ‘›Q\in\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}(n) is a double stochastic matrix. Any distribution over permutations whose expectation equals Qğ‘„Q can be used as a potential prior. In fact, it is known that there are distributions supported over only Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}) (as opposed to n!ğ‘›n!) permutations satisfying that requirement. Identification of the support via Birkhoffâ€™s decomposition [48] requires at least Oâ€‹(n4)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›4O(n^{4}) runtime, and hence is not scalable. In the framework considered here, it is convenient to use M=Qğ‘€ğ‘„M=Q in the prior (7). The mode(s) of that prior are then given by the permutation matrices solving the Euclidean projection problem minÎ âˆˆğ’«â€‹(n)âˆ¥Î âˆ’Qâˆ¥F2\min_{\Pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}\lVert\Pi-Q\rVert_{\textsf{F}}^{2} of Qğ‘„Q on ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n). A basic example for Qğ‘„Q results for the so-called exchangeable linkage model in [28, 30] in which Q=(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹In+Î±nâˆ’1â€‹ğŸnâ€‹ğŸnâŠ¤ğ‘„1ğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ‘›ğ›¼ğ‘›1subscript1ğ‘›superscriptsubscript1ğ‘›topQ=(1-\alpha)I_{n}+\frac{\alpha}{n-1}\bm{1}_{n}\bm{1}_{n}^{\top}. Since in this case âŸ¨Q,Î âŸ©=(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹âŸ¨In,Î âŸ©+Î±â€‹nnâˆ’1ğ‘„Î 1ğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ‘›Î ğ›¼ğ‘›ğ‘›1\left\langle Q,\Pi\right\rangle=(1-\alpha)\left\langle I_{n},\Pi\right\rangle+\alpha\frac{n}{n-1} for Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1), the resulting prior is equivalent to the Hamming prior considered in Example (I). More complex priors are obtained depending on the structure of Qğ‘„Q.

2.3 Integration in Shuffled Data Problems

In this subsection, we outline how the above prior can be integrated into generic shuffled data problems. The proposed Monte-Carlo EM [49] framework builds upon the classical work [33] that has been rediscovered in the more recent work [21]. The Monte-Carlo EM scheme in [33] was further developed based on the concept of data augmentation [50] in Gutman et al.Â [6]. Note that none of [33, 21, 6] consider informative priors for the permutation. Conjugacy. The (conditional) likelihood (9) can be maximized with respect to both Î¸ğœƒ\theta and Ï€ğœ‹\pi as, e.g., in [8, 11, 22]. In an alternative view, Î¸ğœƒ\theta is considered as the quantity of primary interest, in which case one would rather consider the integrated likelihood

Lâ€‹(Î¸)=ğ„Ï€â¡[Lâ€‹(Î¸|Ï€)]=âˆ‘Ï€âˆˆğ’«â€‹(n)Lâ€‹(Î¸|Ï€)â€‹pâ€‹(Ï€).ğ¿ğœƒsubscriptğ„ğœ‹ğ¿conditionalğœƒğœ‹subscriptğœ‹ğ’«ğ‘›ğ¿conditionalğœƒğœ‹ğ‘ğœ‹L(\theta)=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}_{\pi}[L(\theta|\pi)]=\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}(n)}L(\theta|\pi)p(\pi). (11)

As seen in Â§Â§\S2.1, maximizing the conditional likelihood tends to be prone to overfitting, prompting a need for regularization. The use of the integrated likelihood mitigates that problem at best slightly, but not substantially as can be seen, e.g., by examining the case of linear regression with i.i.d.Â Gaussian errors (cf.Â Appendix E), hence regularization remains relevant. Monte Carlo EM scheme The Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm [51] is an established heuristic for (approximately) minimizing the negative log-likelihood corresponding to (11). The surrogates {â„“~(t)â€‹(â‹…;Î¸(t))}superscript~â„“ğ‘¡â‹…superscriptğœƒğ‘¡\{\widetilde{\ell}^{(t)}(\cdot\,;\theta^{(t)})\} tend to be easier to minimize since they are linear combinations of standard likelihood terms as they are encountered for fixed and known Ï€ğœ‹\pi. The Metropolis-Hastings (MH) algorithm can be used to generate a Markov Chain {Ï€(k)}kâ‰¥1subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1\{\pi^{(k)}\}_{k\geq 1} whose stationary distribution equals pâ€‹(Ï€|ğ’Ÿ,Î¸(t))ğ‘conditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}). This yields the approximation

ğ„^â€‹[Ï€iâ€‹j|ğ’Ÿ,Î¸(t)]=1mâˆ’bâ€‹âˆ‘k=b+1mÏ€iâ€‹j(k),(i,j)âˆˆ[n]2.formulae-sequence^ğ„delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡1ğ‘šğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘›2\widehat{\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}}[\pi_{ij}|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]=\frac{1}{m-b}\sum_{k=b+1}^{m}\pi_{ij}^{(k)},\quad(i,j)\in[n]^{2}. (13)

where bğ‘b denotes the length of the so-called â€œburn-inâ€ period after which the Markov Chain is considered to have reached stationarity, and mğ‘šm denotes the total length of the Markov chain. Substituting (13) into (12) then yields what is known as Monte-Carlo EM scheme, summarized in Algorithm 1.

Conveniently, there is a proposal distribution for the MH algorithm that is, in a sense, canonical and easy to work with. That proposal distribution, known as Fisher-Yates sampling, generates a new permutation from the current one by swapping the assignments of a pair of indices (cf.Â Algorithm 2 for details). Initialization. It is a well-known fact that the choice of the initial iterate Î¸(0)superscriptğœƒ0\theta^{(0)} can critically impact the quality of the solution that is returned by EM schemes given that the latter is a local strategy that finds a stationary point of a (in general) non-convex objective near the initial iterate. Several consistent initial estimators of Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*} are known for regression setups depending on the structure of Ï€ğœ‹\pi [22, 24, 47, 28, 29, 23], and those naturally lend themselves as initial iterate for the above EM scheme.

Careful initialization of the MH subroutine is important as well in order to ensure that pâ€‹(Ï€|ğ’Ÿ,Î¸(t))ğ‘conditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) is explored reasonably well given that the domain of interest ğ’«â€‹(n)ğ’«ğ‘›\mathcal{P}(n) has n!ğ‘›n! elements while the number of MCMC iterations mğ‘šm is limited. Fortunately, under the prior (6), computing the mode argmaxÏ€pâ€‹(Ï€|ğ’Ÿ,Î¸(t))subscriptargmaxğœ‹ğ‘conditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡\operatorname*{argmax}_{\pi}p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) reduces to an LAP of the form (7) in virtue of (10). Initialization via the mode has the advantage that the Markov chain is started in a high density region. The hope is that the resulting iterates (which are generated according to a localized proposal distribution) will pick up most of the mass of pâ€‹(Ï€|ğ’Ÿ,Î¸(t))ğ‘conditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡p(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}) so that (13) will well approximate the underlying expectation.

Computational complexity We here discuss the computational complexity of Algorithm 1. For exponential family models benefiting from the above reduction, the M-step, i.e., the update of Î¸ğœƒ\theta only involves nğ‘›n terms, and is hence computationally equivalent to a standard estimation problem. Apart from the initialization of the Markov chain, the approximate E-step has complexity Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m), where mğ‘šm denotes the length of the Markov chain. Computing the acceptance probability, updating Ï€(k)superscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\pi^{(k)}, and keeping tracking of ğ„^â€‹[Î |ğ’Ÿ,Î¸(t)]âŠ¤â€‹ğ˜^ğ„superscriptdelimited-[]conditionalÎ ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒğ‘¡topğ˜\widehat{\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}}[\Pi|\mathcal{D},\theta^{(t)}]^{\top}\mathbf{Y} within Algorithm 2 can be done in time Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) given that the proposal distribution only changes Ï€(k)superscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\pi^{(k)} at two positions. However, mğ‘šm is recommended to be at least of the order Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n), heuristically justified by the fact that in the worst case a permutation is the product of nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1 transpositions. Obtaining the initial permutation Ï€^initsubscript^ğœ‹init\widehat{\pi}_{\text{init}} generally involves the solution of a linear assignment problem, which is costly with a complexity of Oâ€‹(n3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›3O(n^{3}), while approximate solutions via Sinkhorn iterations can be obtained in complexity Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}) [53]. Alternatively, since computing Ï€^initsubscript^ğœ‹init\widehat{\pi}_{\text{init}} based on an LAP is expensive, Ï€^initsubscript^ğœ‹init\widehat{\pi}_{\text{init}} can be initialized as the last state of the Markov chain returned by Algorithm 2 in the previous EM iteration tğ‘¡t, for all EM iterations beyond the first. Data augmentation Following [50] and [6], the Monte-Carlo EM approach can be converted into a Bayesian inference procedure targeting the posterior pâ€‹(Î¸|ğ’Ÿ)ğ‘conditionalğœƒğ’Ÿp(\theta|\mathcal{D}), and along the way also pâ€‹(Ï€|ğ’Ÿ)ğ‘conditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿp(\pi|\mathcal{D}). Since Monte-Carlo EM already involves sampling from the distribution of pâ€‹(Ï€|ğ’Ÿ,Î¸)ğ‘conditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿğœƒp(\pi|\mathcal{D},\theta), one can as well sample from pâ€‹(Î¸|ğ’Ÿ,Ï€)ğ‘conditionalğœƒğ’Ÿğœ‹p(\theta|\mathcal{D},\pi) in an alternating fashion, which can be understood as a specific Gibbs sampler for the joint posterior pâ€‹(Î¸,Ï€|ğ’Ÿ)ğ‘ğœƒconditionalğœ‹ğ’Ÿp(\theta,\pi|\mathcal{D}). Such sampling scheme is particularly attractive whenever it is easy to sample from pâ€‹(Î¸|ğ’Ÿ,Ï€)ğ‘conditionalğœƒğ’Ÿğœ‹p(\theta|\mathcal{D},\pi). This is the case, e.g., for the Gaussian linear regression setting with conjugate priors for the regression parameter Î²ğ›½\beta and the error variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, as well as for the precision matrix estimation problem for multivariate Normal data described above with an inverse Wishart prior for Î©Î©\Omega. Compared to the Monte-Carlo EM approach, sampling from pâ€‹(Î¸|ğ’Ÿ,Ï€)ğ‘conditionalğœƒğ’Ÿğœ‹p(\theta|\mathcal{D},\pi) has potential advantages from the standpoint of inference (approximate standard errors and construction of credibility intervals). An illustrative example is presented in Â§Â§\S4.

Beyond permutations We would like to point out that the framework presented herein does not require Ï€ğœ‹\pi to be a permutation. Specifically, we may be given two separate files ğ’Ÿğ±={ğ±i}i=1Nsubscriptğ’Ÿğ±superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘\mathcal{D}_{\mathbf{x}}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N} and ğ’Ÿğ²={ğ²i}i=1nsubscriptğ’Ÿğ²superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{\mathbf{y}}=\{\mathbf{y}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, N>nğ‘ğ‘›N>n (without loss of generality), and the consider maps Ï€:{1,â€¦,n}â†’{1,â€¦,N}:ğœ‹â†’1â€¦ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘\pi:\{1,\ldots,n\}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,N\} with corresponding matrix Î âˆˆ{0,1}nÃ—NÎ superscript01ğ‘›ğ‘\Pi\in\{0,1\}^{n\times N} with row sums equal to one. Letting ğ’«â€‹(n,N)ğ’«ğ‘›ğ‘\mathcal{P}(n,N) denote the set of all such matrices/maps, we can define a prior of the form (6) given a mode Mâˆˆâ„nÃ—Nğ‘€superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘M\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times N}. Conditional and integrated likelihoods can be defined analogously to (9) and (11), and the conjugacy property (10) continues to hold. The proposed computational Monte-Carlo EM scheme remains applicable with minor modifications in Algorithm 2, inclusive the reduction for exponential family likelihoods.

3 Theoretical Insights

In this section, we present some analysis on the proposed prior from the perspective of regularization. The main purpose of the analysis is to provide additional guidance on the choice of the concentration parameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma in regression problems. Hamming prior. Our first results concerns the MAP estimator of Î âˆ—superscriptÎ \Pi^{*} under the Hamming prior (8). Specifically, we consider the linear regression setup

yi=Î¼Ï€âˆ—â€‹(i)â€‹(ğ±)+Ïƒâˆ—â€‹Ïµi,Î¼iâ€‹(ğ±)=ğ±iâŠ¤â€‹Î²âˆ—,ğ±iâˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,Id),1â‰¤iâ‰¤n,{Ïµi}i=1nâ€‹âˆ¼i.i.d.â€‹Nâ€‹(0,1),formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡superscriptğœ‹ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğœsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ±superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–topsuperscriptğ›½formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘0subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘1ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›i.i.d.similar-toğ‘01y_{i}=\mu_{\pi^{*}(i)}(\mathbf{x})+\sigma_{*}\epsilon_{i},\quad\mu_{i}(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top}\beta^{*},\quad\mathbf{x}_{i}\sim N(0,I_{d}),1\leq i\leq n,\quad\{\epsilon_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}\overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim}N(0,1), (14)

as considered in a series of prior works on shuffled linear regression [8, 11, 10, 22]. The statement below considers the sparse setting with the underlying permutation Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} satisfying the constraint dHâ€‹(Ï€âˆ—,id)â‰¤ksubscriptğ‘‘Hsuperscriptğœ‹idğ‘˜d_{\textsf{H}}(\pi^{*},\textsf{id})\leq k for kğ‘˜k â€œsmall enoughâ€ as made precise below. with probability at least 1âˆ’2/n12ğ‘›1-2/n and 1âˆ’3/n13ğ‘›1-3/n, respectively, where ğ›=(Î¼iâ€‹(ğ±))i=1nğ›superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ±ğ‘–1ğ‘›\bm{\mu}=(\mu_{i}(\mathbf{x}))_{i=1}^{n}.

Let us briefly comment on the implications of Theorem 1. Theorem 1 provides guidance on the choice of Î³ğ›¾\gamma for a specific setup. In addition, solver accuracy can degrade with the magnitude of the entries [54].

4 Experiments

In this section, we present the results of experiments conducted with synthetic and real data. At the end of the section, we also show an example demonstrating the use of the data augmentation approach discussed at the end of Â§Â§\S2.3 as an alternative to the Monte-Carlo EM scheme. The MATLAB code underlying the results shown herein can be accessed from https://github.com/bruce1edward/exp_prior_shuffled_data. Synthetic data. We consider data generation according to the following three models:

We fix n=1,000ğ‘›1000n=1,000, d=20ğ‘‘20d=20, Ïƒâˆ—=1subscriptğœ1\sigma_{*}=1, Ïâˆ—=0.8subscriptğœŒ0.8\rho_{*}=0.8, p=q=5ğ‘ğ‘5p=q=5, B=50ğµ50B=50. The mismatch rates k/nğ‘˜ğ‘›k/n and kâ‹…B/nâ‹…ğ‘˜ğµğ‘›k\cdot B/n in (15)(i) and (15)(iii), respectively, are varied between 0.20.20.2 and 0.50.50.5 in steps of 0.050.050.05, and the bandwidth rğ‘Ÿr in (15)(ii) is varied between 333 and 101010. For each setup and each value of kğ‘˜k and rğ‘Ÿr, 100 independent replications are performed.

The following approaches are compared:

(I) naive. Standard maximum likelihood estimation as used for parameter estimation in the absence of mismatches, which corresponds to fixing Ï€=idğœ‹id\pi=\textsf{id} as the identity permutation. (II) oracle. The unknown permutation Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} is considered as known, and standard maximum likelihood estimation is used for parameter estimation after fixing Ï€=Ï€âˆ—ğœ‹superscriptğœ‹\pi=\pi^{*}. (III) robust [for setting kğ‘˜k-Sparse only]. For setup LR, the regression parameter is estimated on the robustfit function in MATLAB [55]. For setup GLM, the regression parameter is estimated based on the robust GLM estimation method [56] that uses observation-specific dummy variables and penalization. For setup MVN, Î©âˆ—âˆ’1superscriptsubscriptÎ©1\Omega_{*}^{-1} is estimated according to the robustcov function in MATLAB [55] which implements the minimum covariance determinant estimator in [57]. (IV) EM, EMH, EML, EMB. Algorithm 1 using uniform, Hamming, local shuffling, and block-Hamming prior, respectively, where the latter three reflect the constraint sets (i) to (iii) in (15). The EM iterations are initialized by setting Ï€=idğœ‹id\pi=\textsf{id}, and the number of EM iterations is limited to 400. The number of MCMC iterations per EM iteration is set to 8k, half of which are counted towards the â€œburn-in periodâ€. We note that a modified MH algorithm is used for EML (cf.Â Appendix F); for EMB, the MH scheme in Algorithm 2 is applied block by block. For the Sparse and SparseBlock settings, the hyperparameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma is chosen based on Proposition 1, which suggests Î³âˆlogâ¡(n)proportional-toğ›¾ğ‘›\gamma\propto\log(n). For the Banded setting, the choice Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 was found to yield good performance. (V) Lahiri & Larsen (LL), Chambers (C) [for setting kğ‘˜k-SparseBlock only]. The approaches described in [28] and [47] with the choice Q=ğ„â¡[Î âˆ—]=IBâŠ—Q0ğ‘„ğ„superscriptÎ tensor-productsubscriptğ¼ğµsubscriptğ‘„0Q=\operatorname{\mathbf{E}}[\Pi^{*}]=I_{B}\otimes Q_{0}, where Q0=(1âˆ’Î±âˆ—)â€‹In/B+Î±âˆ—â€‹ğŸn/Bâ€‹ğŸn/BâŠ¤subscriptğ‘„01subscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ‘›ğµsubscriptğ›¼subscript1ğ‘›ğµsuperscriptsubscript1ğ‘›ğµtopQ_{0}=(1-\alpha_{*})I_{n/B}+\alpha_{*}\mathbf{1}_{n/B}\mathbf{1}_{n/B}^{\top}, Î±âˆ—=(kâ‹…B)/nsubscriptğ›¼â‹…ğ‘˜ğµğ‘›\alpha_{*}=(k\cdot B)/n. For setup MVN, the LL approach amounts to estimation of Î©âˆ—subscriptÎ©\Omega_{*} by the inverse of the modified sample covariance matrix S~~ğ‘†\widetilde{S} with blocks S~ğ±ğ±=ğ—âŠ¤â€‹ğ—/nsubscript~ğ‘†ğ±ğ±superscriptğ—topğ—ğ‘›\widetilde{S}_{\mathbf{x}\mathbf{x}}=\mathbf{X}^{\top}\mathbf{X}/n, S~ğ±ğ²=ğ—âŠ¤â€‹QâŠ¤â€‹ğ˜/nsubscript~ğ‘†ğ±ğ²superscriptğ—topsuperscriptğ‘„topğ˜ğ‘›\widetilde{S}_{\mathbf{x}\mathbf{y}}=\mathbf{X}^{\top}Q^{\top}\mathbf{Y}/n, and S~ğ²ğ²=ğ˜âŠ¤â€‹ğ˜/nsubscript~ğ‘†ğ²ğ²superscriptğ˜topğ˜ğ‘›\widetilde{S}_{\mathbf{y}\mathbf{y}}=\mathbf{Y}^{\top}\mathbf{Y}/n.

(VI) Averaging [for setting rğ‘Ÿr-Banded only]. We compute (componentwise) running averages of the {ğ±i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and {ğ²i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{\mathbf{y}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} within sliding windows of size rğ‘Ÿr, and estimate the parameters Î²âˆ—superscriptğ›½\beta^{*} and Î©âˆ—subscriptÎ©\Omega_{*} from these local averages in the usual way (i.e., if these were the original and uncontaminated data).

For better comparison across different experimental configurations, we visualize the relative estimation error (REE) âˆ¥Î²estâˆ’Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2/âˆ¥Î²âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½estsuperscriptğ›½2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ›½2\lVert\beta^{\text{est}}-\beta^{*}\rVert_{2}/\lVert\beta^{*}\rVert_{2} and âˆ¥Correstâˆ’Corrâˆ—âˆ¥Fsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptCorrestsuperscriptCorrF\lVert\text{Corr}^{\text{est}}-\text{Corr}^{*}\rVert_{\textsf{F}} , where Î²estsuperscriptğ›½est\beta^{\text{est}} and CorrestsuperscriptCorrest\text{Corr}^{\text{est}} are a placeholder for the aforementioned estimators; Corr refers to the correlation matrix corresponding to Î©âˆ—âˆ’1superscriptsubscriptÎ©1\Omega_{*}^{-1}. Selected results are shown in Figure 3, which displays averages of the REE over 100 replications for each model and each permutation. Overall, it can be seen that EMB, EMH, EML achieve significant improvements over their unregularized counterpart and the other baseline methods under consideration.

Real data. We consider seven benchmark data sets for shuffled data problems as tabulated in Table 1. The data sets are preprocessed versions of their original counterparts. The details of data processing can be found in the corresponding reference provided in Table 1. Even though the data sets themselves are real, the permutations that scramble the given matching pairs {(ğ±i,ğ²i)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ²ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{n} are synthetic. Specifically, for each data set, we consider 100 independent random permutations depending on the underlying setting. We consider the same list of competitors and associated configurations as for the synthetic data experiments. Asterisked ground truth parameters here refer to oracle estimates based on knowledge of Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*}, and relative estimation error (REE) is defined accordingly in terms of those (pseudo)-ground truth parameters.

Hamming and Block prior. As can be seen from Figure 4, the proposed approach consistently improves over naive least squares once the fraction of mismatches exceeds 0.2, and yields significant improvements as that fraction increases. The regularized EM approach with specific prior (i.e. EMB, EMH, EML) noticeable reduces error induced by shuffling.

Local shuffling prior. As shown in the Table 2, the EM approach with local shuffling prior achieves significant error reductions compared to the naive approach and the EM approach without regularization.

Data Augmentation

In this paragraph we present a brief illustration of the proposed approach when used in conjunction with data augmentation, i.e., both the parameter and the permutation are sampled in an alternating fashion (cf.Â discussion at the end of Â§Â§\S2.3). For this purpose, we consider the Italian household survey discussed in [58], see also Table 1. This data set involves a simple linear regression problem in which the household income (in 1k Euros) in 2010 is is regressed on the same quantity in 2008, including an intercept term.

The process of file linkage subject to mismatch error involving the income data from the two years under consideration is simulated by generating a permutation Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*} uniformly at random from the Hamming ball of radius kğ‘˜k around the identity permutation, where k/n=0.4ğ‘˜ğ‘›0.4k/n=0.4.

We compare both the unregularized case with the uniform prior for Ï€ğœ‹\pi as well as the regularized case with the Hamming prior (8) (Î³=logâ¡nğ›¾ğ‘›\gamma=\log n in view of Proposition 1).

Figure 5 confirms that the proposed approach achieves visible improvements over the unregularized approach which suffers from serious amplification bias affecting the slope parameter Î²1subscriptğ›½1\beta_{1} and serious underestimation of the error variance, as predicted by the brief analysis accompanying the first introductory example in Â§Â§\S2.1.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a framework for regularized estimation in shuffled data problems by means of an exponential family prior on the permutation group. As elaborated above, the exponential family form is convenient for computational purposes yet sufficiently rich to incorporate various common forms of prior knowledge. In particular, the prior is not tailored to specific data analysis problems, but can be applied generically. The results in this paper confirm the importance of regularization in shuffled data problems given the inherent danger of overfitting already in the presence of little noise. While the approach covers a variety of constraints that can be imposed on the underlying permutation, it is certainly not exhaustive: not all sorts of prior knowledge can be captured via the prior proposed herein. For example, suppose we have information on the cycles of the permutation (numbers and/or lengths). Such information cannot be expressed in terms of index pairs, and hence requires a different paradigm. Several authors [59, 60] have considered the Fourier analysis on the permutation group [43] to facilitate learning problems involving permutations, and it is an interesting direction of future research to study how that approach can be leveraged for the type of shuffled data problems considered in the present paper. Moreover, we herein have focused on the situation where exactly two files are merged. It is of interest to consider more complex situations arising from linkage of several files and multiple permutations as well as the modeling of potential dependencies among those: for examples, the permutations might be completely unrelated, or identical [25, 61], or involve intermediate situations with varying degrees of overlap.
